Expectation1: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation1: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story: The phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was about to slip into the chapel for the special healing service. The air was thick with incense, and the sisters’ voices echoed softly through the halls. I glanced at the screen—my new client, Mr. Lee, calling right on time for his check-in. He’d mentioned he was nervous about using the new machine, and I knew he was expecting me to walk him through the basics, to reassure him. But the abbess had asked all of us to be present for Sister Agnes’s healing prayers, a rare and urgent gathering. My heart pounded as I weighed the phone in my hand. The community needed my presence, my prayers, my faith. But Mr. Lee needed my expertise, my calm instructions. I could hear the opening hymn begin, the voices rising in hope, while Mr. Lee’s anxious greeting crackled through the phone. I stood frozen in the corridor, torn between the world of machines and the world of faith, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
